item.title: Report E-2023120226
item.description:
Report E-2023120226

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-20T18:13:21+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-08
  • City: PACOIMA
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 8, 2023, one (1) 2.5 gallon jug of ZeroTol 2.0 was crushed in transit and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Ten West Environmental (TWE) to remediate the impacted site. TWE personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and soda ash to remediate the ZeroTol-impacted impacted trailer. The crew de palletized, re palletized, and shrink wrapped the freight for the customer. TWE personnel solidified and neutralized the damaged jug of product. The damaged jug and all impacted debris were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon poly vented drums and stored on site for transport and disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023120224
item.description:
Report E-2023120224

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-20T18:13:21+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-08
  • City: MONTEBELLO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 6, 2023, one (1) one-gallon bottle of UN2398 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the impacted site. The one (1) damaged bottle was removed for waste, and the other three (3) bottles in the cardboard box were wiped down and staged for return back to the shipper. GES personnel restacked all undamaged freight for further shipment and processing. One (1) 5-gallon bucket that contained the one (1) damaged bottle, absorbent pads, and any cleanup debris was staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was found wet. Upon inspection one of the items had a loose cap. Spilled inside. We sealed the item and placed it in a Hazmat bag and then in a Hazmat tote. DescribePack: The failure was due to a loose cap on one of the containers. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Item was sealed properly, placed in a Hazmat bag and Hazmat drum.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The package was found to have a wet spot on the outer container. Package was place in a hazmat bag and tote and taken for inspection. upon inspection we found one of the two bottles had a loose cap causing it to leak about 4 oz of product on to the outer container. all clean up material was kept with package. DescribePack: One of the two bottles had a loose cap causing to leak. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was placed in a hazmat bag and tote.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was been moved on the belt when it was mishandled, package was pushed, dropped on the concrete floor and started leaking. DescribePack: The cap of the bottles got cracked opened when it hit the floor and started leaking. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: It was brought to the attention of a trained admin who quickly went with the equipment needed to retrieve the package and put in a place where it could not cause any harm.

item.title: Report E-2023120205
item.description:
Report E-2023120205

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-18T21:10:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-04
  • City: SAN LORENZO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 4, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN1230 was punctured and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Patriot Environmental Services (PES) to remediate the site. PES personnel deployed granular absorbents to the methanol-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. Crews transferred the product into a new 330-gallon tote.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: This package was discovered in the unload and inspected by QA. Package was placed in a hazmat bin and inspected with gloves and masks at the QA work area. DescribePack: One bottle had a loose cap and almost fully spilled out. Only one bottle had spilled. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was placed inside multiple layers of plastic liners to prevent further leakage and taken out of the unload to be processed.

item.title: Report I-2023110029
item.description:
Report I-2023110029

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-21T00:34:05+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-26
  • City: AZUSA
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PACIFIC PETROLEUM CALIFORNIA, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: PPC employee and receiving facility employee were unloading the drums from inside the trailer to a location outside. The employees tried to use a pallet jack but were unable to get it under the pallet. The employees proceeded to take one drum at a time from off of the pallet and move them by dolly. There was no sign or indication that the drum was leaking when the employees were moving the drums. When the receiving facility employee moved the last drum, the bottom of the drum cracked. The crack was a total failure (please see attached photo #1) and all fluid was released quickly inside the trailer. The fluids ran out of the trailer and onto the asphalt where it gathered along the cement curb. Employees worked together and set down absorbent boom and pads to contain the waste from spreading further. Fluids stayed onsite in the immediate area and didn't enter any waterways, public property or roads. Internal response team from the facility cleaned up the spill. Waste materials were then collected and placed into new drums for disposal.
